{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3136963,"name":"Peter","username":"BeastieWaffles","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/beastiewaffles/{size}/182272_2.png","created_at":"2023-01-31T15:10:29.640Z","cooked":"

Have any teams had much luck with 3D printing bearing blocks? I’ve seen several threads but haven’t been able to successfully locate a CAD for something like the versa blocks (other than what’s on the vex website). I’ve seen thread like this but never found a link to any sort of CAD.

To those who have tried using 3D printed bearing blocks, what were your experiences? What worked and what didn’t? Any advice when trying to pursue this? We plan to print in PetG.

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":8,"updated_at":"2023-01-31T15:10:29.640Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":372,"reads":329,"readers_count":328,"score":1925.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":425221,"topic_slug":"3d-printed-bearing-block","display_username":"Peter","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/3d-printed-versa-blocks/391397","internal":true,"reflection":false,"title":"3D Printed Versa Blocks","clicks":76}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":53708,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Waffles | Team Captain"},"post_url":"/t/3d-printed-bearing-block/425221/1","custom_user_title":"Waffles | Team Captain","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3137044,"name":"","username":"TheSnowHatHero","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/thesnowhathero/{size}/231822_2.png","created_at":"2023-01-31T16:51:45.809Z","cooked":"

This isn’t my story, but some alumni on my team advised us against using printed blocks, saying that they “exploded” during one of their matches. Thankfully, this was something being tried over the offseason, but the point stands.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":8,"updated_at":"2023-01-31T16:51:45.809Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":288,"readers_count":287,"score":87.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":425221,"topic_slug":"3d-printed-bearing-block","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":55003,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"2502 Engineering Captain"},"post_url":"/t/3d-printed-bearing-block/425221/2","custom_user_title":"2502 Engineering Captain","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3137051,"name":"D_Price (1708 Co-Lead Mentor)","username":"D_Price","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/d_price/{size}/255556_2.png","created_at":"2023-01-31T17:05:42.652Z","cooked":"

Please do not do this unless you have access to a printer like a Mark-Forged that can print a very durable filament like Carbon Fiber and Nylon+ (but this will also depend on the application of the bearing block.) PLA is durable only for specific applications so be aware when using.

TheSnowHatHero:

This isn’t my story, but some alumni on my team advised us against using printed blocks, saying that they “exploded” during one of their matches. Thankfully, this was something being tried over the offseason, but the point stands.

Also taking context from the above hyperlink you posted see below.

3D Printed Versa Blocks

While they are weaker, yes, with the CURA settings I have now they are as strong as they need to be. I would never mount a motor onto them, but I wouldn’t put shooter setups and arms past their abilities. Bare PLA works well for these. Maybe you could acetone vapor smooth some abs but that would only help with durability over time. However, it’d probably be easier to just replace them. I’ve got a mildly upgraded Ender 3. All metal feeder assembly, upgraded bowden tubing, a bltouch, glass bed, and an enhanced cooler. Sizing varies but I’ve found that printing the stock V2 versa with the large rectangle-like holes filled in at 100.5% with a 0.8 nozzle fits the tube stock just like the ones that come from Vex do. The upgrades I have help with accuracy but it’s not like these couldn’t be printed with a stock Ender 3. It’d just take a little more time to get it dialed in.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":8,"updated_at":"2023-01-31T17:05:42.652Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":11,"reads":255,"readers_count":254,"score":121.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":425221,"topic_slug":"3d-printed-bearing-block","display_username":"D_Price (1708 Co-Lead Mentor)","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/3d-printed-versa-blocks/391397/9","internal":true,"reflection":false,"title":"3D Printed Versa Blocks","clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":7445,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Robotics Lifer"},"post_url":"/t/3d-printed-bearing-block/425221/3","custom_user_title":"Robotics Lifer","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3137058,"name":"Kyle Swaidner","username":"kswaid","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/k/df788c/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-01-31T17:10:24.232Z","cooked":"

We have successfully used printed bearing blocks for drivetrain, intake linkages, and other mechanisms in the past. The keys are to use appropriately tough materials (nylon, polycarb, hard TPU) rather than PLA, design with printing in mind (consider layer bonding vs. planar strength), and use wall thickness instead of infill percentage to increase strength and stiffness. All my examples are lost on some dead hard drive, but you can easily design a test example and destructively test it to get a feel for strength and durability.

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":8,"updated_at":"2023-01-31T17:10:24.232Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":213,"readers_count":212,"score":57.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":425221,"topic_slug":"3d-printed-bearing-block","display_username":"Kyle Swaidner","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":26091,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"FRC #1740 Cyber Colonels"},"post_url":"/t/3d-printed-bearing-block/425221/4","custom_user_title":"FRC #1740 Cyber Colonels","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3137066,"name":"Nick Aarestad","username":"cadandcookies","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/cadandcookies/{size}/158154_2.png","created_at":"2023-01-31T17:39:25.200Z","cooked":"

If you do go the route of printing them, I would probably recommend designing your own to take advantage of the non-isotropic properties of 3D prints, and to add material/thickness where necessary. You can, to a certain extent, make up the gap for even a PETG or PLA+ with more material/volume and clever design. Printing an aluminum part as-is without considering the different DFM characteristics of a printer is a recipe for pain.

I printed some with our Markforged Onyx One and they appear to be holding up fine.
